div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello." The climate of Cyprus is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head:
The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager--R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
div.p: Commenting upon the active opposition of President Roosevelt against the trusts the "Times" remarks.

President Roosevelt, speaking at Provincetown, where he laid the corner-stone of the Pilgrim Memorial monument, observed that he had received countless requests and suggestions, both public and private, that he should do or say something to ease the situation. Dealing with these requests, he intimated very plainly that he does not believe the financial disturbance to be of his making. That disturbance, he points ont, is universal. It is felt on the Bourses of the Continent and on the London Stock Exchange just as much as in New York. That is true, but it is not, taken by itself, a convincing argument. Every considerable disturbance is nowadays felt in all the great financial centres because they are closely connected and inter-dependent, while the telegraph renders movements practically simultaneous all over the world. In such circumstances it is not easy to prove beyond cavil that disturbance begins at any given spot, especially when, as at present, trade is generally active, and everything is working at high pressure. The rule is that every exchange places the origin of disturbance somewhere else, and tries to pose as the innocent victim of speculation in less cautious and well-ordered centres. The exact truth of the matter is difficult to ascertain, and most difficult of all when it suits New York to accept the blame which London and Paris are glad to throw upon it. Just now New York is pleased to be regarded as the storm-centre because Wall street finds it convenient to pass on the charge to President Roosevelt. If he cannot mathematically prove that other centres are just as disturbed as New York on their own account, he can at least show cause for strongly suspecting this to be the case. Speculation has been lively in the Old World as well as in the New. In both alike there has been a great absorption of capital by business undertakings eager to make the most of trade activity while it lasts, and accordingly we may expect in both cases monetary stringency and a fall in the value of securities. It is worth remembering that there have been periods of stringency and falling securities before now, when there was no President proposing to deal with dishonest corporations. We may therefore receive with considerable reserve the theory that President Roosevelt's policy is responsible for things at least susceptible of a totally different explanation. He hints not obscurely that the disturbance has been artificially increased in New York by the wealthy men whose alleged malpractices he attacks, in order to get up a public scare at the prospect of reform. What we know of the ways of Wall street and of corporations cannot be said to render this theory wholly incredible.

The President, at all events, announces his unwavering determination to continue in the course he has marked out for himaelf. He says it is idle to ask him not to prosecute criminals whether rich or poor, but he repeats as he has done many times before, that he entertains no hostility to corporations as such or to men of wealth as such. He declares emphatically that no vindictive action has been or will be undertaken, and that he intends to pursue his end of purifying corporation business with as little harshness as possible and with the greatest anxiety not to inflict undeserved suffering upon innocent stockholders.

The Standard Oil Company has issued a circular complaining that it is pursued with causeless hostility by the Government, that it is absolutely innocent of all the charges brought against it, that it is the victim of technicalities mercilessly used, and that the one grief of its manager is that half a million people interested in it are going to suffer. That sort of thing will no doubt have its effect; but, if Mr. Taft and the President are right in believing that there is a great and general awakening of the public conscience, the moans of these interested parties will not seriously affect the course of affairs. It is at least significant in this connexion that those who leap from the Republican frying-pan will only land in the Democratic fire. Mr. Bryan goes further than Mr. Roosevelt, and proclaims absolute hostility to all big trusts, whether managed one way or the other. The American people will, no doubt, find means to sift good from bad, and to impose reasonable restrictions with nothing but benefit to honest enterprise.

div.p: The debut of the Galenzi troupe of French comedy at the Alhambra Theatre last night was a great success and was attended by a large audience, including the Governor. To-night "Triplepatte" is again to be staged and for to-morrow "Le Vieux Marcheur" is billed.

div.head: Distribution of prizes.
div.p: The distribution of prizes to the students' of the Islamic School "Abu El Abbass" took place this morning under the presidency of the Rev. Sheikh Shaker, Cheif Imam at Alexandria. Hussain Pasha Fakhry, Regent, Mazloum Pasha, the Governor and many notable's were present. Sheikh Shaker delivered an eloquent address on the Islamic region.

div.head: CAIRO DRINKING WATER.
div.p: As mentiond by us in a recent issue a deputation visited the Regent and Sir Eldon Gorst to present a complaint against the artesian well water in Cairo, the principal points of which are :—
That the water from the artesian wells is not "artesian" in the sense understood by all the world.
That it is not hygienic as contended by the Water Company.
That it is very detrimental to the health of the inhabitants.
That it occasions many internal maladies, such as gastritis and enteritis, as well as diseases of the skin.

That it weakens the body and causes it to lose its vigour. Its effeets are most noticeable upon women and children, and it bas certainly contributed in a great degree to the mortality which has not ceased to increase since the water has been in use.
That it has a bad odour, a bad taste, and often changes in colour, for it is sometimes blackish, sometimes reddish and sometimes greenish.
That it causes the hair to fall and to whiten rapidly, it destroys the clothes and the white linen especially, and it strongly oxidizes metal utensils and renders their use very dangerous.

It leaves a residue of lime in copper vessels, and destroys the soldering of lead pipes ; it is equally probable that it brings with it a certain quantity of lead, for numbers of those suffering from serious illnesses show symptoms in all points resembling those produced by lead on the human body.

It is, in short, impossible to purify in all ways the water in question, and to render it fit for drinking purposes, and the needs of the house, while its use in its present state greatly endangers the health and the life of the inhahitants.
As to the fact that the wells in question are not really "artesian" in a hygienic and medical sense, and that they contam many salts and residues dangerous to health.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
EXAMINATIONS IN ARABIC.
div.p: On the 22nd inst. Mr. John Robertson asked, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he can now state what knowledge of Arabic is required of British officials under the Egyptian Ministry of Public Instruction and give the statistics of the examinations ; and can he also give any information as to the rate of pension and salaries payable to Native and British judges respectively, and as to the inspectors appointed in the Slave Trade Repression Department in Egypt. [22nd August 1907.]

Secretary Sir Edward Grey.—With regard to the first Question, British teachers in Egyptian Government schools and: British officials attached to the Ministry of Education are not required to show any proficiency in Arabic prior to their appointment.
Appointments under the Ministry of Education, as in other branches of. the Egyptian Civil Service, are, however, probationary for a period of not less than one year or more than two years.

With the exception of certain senior officials, whose appointment depends upon the possession of special technical qualifications, all British officials under the Ministry or Education are required to show proficiency in speaking, reading, and writing current Egyptian Arabic before they can be confirmed in their appointment or recommended for any increase of salary.

Regulations instituting such an examination optionally were first enacted in 1898. In 1900 the elementary examination was made compulsory, and an advanced examination in modern Arabic and an honours examination in classical Arabic were instituted. The compulsory clause in the regulations of 1900 is not retroactive, but all except four of the British officials to whom the clause, if retroactive, would have been applicable, have voluntarily passed the elementary examination.

Only 12 of the British officials now serving under the Ministry of Education have been exempted as specialists from the obligation of passing the examination as a condition of their appointinent on the permanent staff; apart from these exemptions the regulations have been rigorously enforced.
The advanced and honours examinations are optional, but promotion depends in a large measure upon an official passing at least the advanced examination.
The number of British officials who have passed the tests during the last five years is as follows :—

The examinations are held in April and November, and officials who fail at one exami- nation are allowed to present themselves at any examination, subject to the condition that unless they pass the elementary examina- tion within the two years' limit of their probationary service they become liable to dismissal.

With regard to the number of failures at the elementary examination, 76 British teachers and other officials employed under the Ministry of Education passed the examination on presenting themselves for the first time, and 22 on presenting themselves for the second time, whilst three who have presented them- selves once and one who has presented himself twice have not yet passed the examination.
With regard to the second Question, in the Mixed Courts the annual salaries of the Native judges are : —

row.cell: President of the Court of Appeal
Judge of the Court of Appeal
President of Court of First Instance (Cairo)
Judge of Court of First Instance

div.p: These judges are entitled to pension, see page 5 infra.
The annual salaries of the British judges are 7 —
Judge of the Court of Appeal, L.E. 1,850 (of which £E1,543 is true salary and £E 307 is an indemnity in lieu of pension).
Judge of Court of First Instance, £E1,388 (of which £E1,157 is true salary and L.E. 231 is an indemnity in lieu of pension).
These judges are not entitled to pension.
In the Native Civil and Criminal Courts the present salaries of the Native judges are :—

row.cell: President of the Court of Appeal.
Judges of the Court of Appeal
Presidents of Courts of First Instance
Vice-Presidents of Courts of First Instance
Judges of Court of First Instance, five classes

div.p: The salaries of the British judges are :—

row.cell: Vice-President of the Court of Appeal.
Judges of Court of First Instance

div.p: All the above Native and British judges are entitled to pension. See page 5, infra.
The history of the above salaries is as follows :—

The Court of Appeal was established in February 1884, the president (Native) being entitled to a salary of L.E. 1,200, the vice-president(Native to L.E. 900, Native judges to L.E. 720, Native assistant judges (juges suppleants) to L.E. 540, and British judges to L.E. 962.
In 1899 a British vice-president was appointed with a salary of L.E. 1,200.
In 1902 the salaries of Native: judges were raised to L.E. 800 and of British judges to L.E. 1,000
In 1904 the salaries of the Native president and of the British vice-president were both raised to L.E. 1,500.
In 1905 the salaries of judges doing assize court work were raised, Native judges to L.E. 1,000, and British judges to L.E. 1,200.
In 1907 the British vice-president's salary was raised to L.E. 1,750.

The Courts of First Instance were established in Lower Egypt in February 1884, presidents (Native) being entitled to salaries of L.E. 600 and L.E. 720, vice-presidents (Native) to L.E. 480 and L.E. 600, Native judges to L.E. 420, Native assistant judges to L.E. 264, and British judges to L.E. 700.

Similar courts were established in Upper Egypt in June 1889, presidents (Native) being entitled to a salary of L.E. 420, vice- presidents (Native) to L.E. 386, Native judges to L.E. 300, Native assistant judges to L.E 174.

In 1893 the salaries of presidents in Upper Egypt were raised to L.E. 540, of vice-presidents in Upper Egypt to L.E. 480, and of vice-presidents in Lower Egypt to L.E. 540. At the same time all the Native judges for both Upper and Lower Egypt were divided into the five classes existing at the present day.
In 1903 the salaries of the presidents of Cairo and Alexandria were raised to L.E. 800, and those of presidents in Upper Egypt to L.E. 600, and of vice-presidents in Upper Egypt to L.E. 540.
In 1905 British judges were first appointed in Upper Egypt, and at the same time the salaries of British judges in both Upper and Lower Egypt were put on the present footing.
In the Muhammadan Ecclesiastical Courts all the judges are Natives. Their present salaries are as follows :—

row.cell: Judges of Central Court of Cairo
Judges and Muftis of Central Courts

div.p: All these judges are entitled to pension.
As regards the history of these salaries it appears that in 1876 the Grand Cadi and the presidents and judges of the Central Courts at Cairo and Alexandria were drawing their present salaries.
Before 1884 the presidents of the Central Courts were receiving salaries up to L.E. 144 and the judges' and muftis' salaries up to L.E. 84.
In that year the salaries of the presidents were raised to L.E. 144 to 240 and of the judges and muftis to L.E. 84 to 96. In 1907 the salaries of judge and muftis were raised to the present figure.

In 1880 the salaries of jadges of the district courts were up to L.E. 60; in that year they were increased to L.E. 60 to 72; in 1891 they they were all equalised at L.E. 72; and in the present year the salaries of about half of these judges bave been raised to L.E. 120.
As regards pensions as mentioned above the British judges of the Mixed Courts are not entitled to any.

Six Native judges of the Native Courts are entitled to a pension, under the provisions of the Pension Law of Said Pasha (26th December 1854), at the rate of one-fourth of their last year's salary after 15 year's service, one-third after 20 years, one-half after 25 years, two-thirds after 30 years, and to a pension equal to their last year's salary after 40 years service.

Three Native judges of the Native Courts are entitled to a pension, under the Pension Law of Ismail Pasha (11th June 1871), at the rate of one-fourth of their last year's salary after 30 years' service.

All the other judges above-mentioned, viz. Native judges of the Mixed Courts, of the Native Civil and Criminal Courts, and of the Muhammadan Ecclesiastical Courts, and British judges of the Native Courts, are subject to the provisions of the Pension Law of 21st June 1887. A judge who has entered the Government service under the age of 35, has served for 25 years, and attained the age of 55, is entitled to pension under this Law.

The basis of this pension is the average annual salary drawn by him during the last three years of his service, and he is entitled to a pension at the rate of one-sixtieth of this average salary of every year's service. This pension cannot exceed either L.E. 600, or three-quarters of his average salary.
With regard to the third question the follow- ing officials were appointed to the Slave Trade Department daring the years 1905-6:—

F.J. Atterbury appointed Inspector on January 1st 1905, at a salary of L.E. 300 per annum.
Mr. Brander Dunbar, appointed Inspector on January 1st 1906 at a salary of L.E. 500 per annum.
Resigned and replaced by—Mr. Akers Douglas, appointed Inspector on July 11th, 1906 at a salary of L.E. 500 per annum.
Mr. Lake Geere appointed Inspector on January 1st, 1906, at a salary of L.E. 500 per annum.

div.head:
THE COTTON SEASON.
REPORT FROM LIVERPOOL.
div.p: We have received by mail' the following cotton report from Messrs. Reynolds and Gibson, of Liverpool and signed' by Messrs, Haywood and Co.

So far back as January the Continent purchased winter futures against long dated sales of yarn, and this was persisted in until March and April, a considerable accumulation taking place. The effect of these purchases was to give the opportunity for: those holding much low cotton to transfer. their hedges. from» near months to more distant positions, where they have remained. The persistent demand : from the trade has kept up the relative price of the current month, as it came along, to a satisfactory premium over the distant hedges, permitting those who had held such distant cotton to sell to advantage, but those whose hedges remained in near cotton tendered their cotton, which has accumulated inthe hands of a few houses. who are obviously hedged with distant futures, this the Continental lock up represents the hedges of the large stock oflow cotton. So far thus is all right and plain sailing, but the question, will shortly arise—how soon will the trade bégin to purchase low cotton? It is believed that the prices of low and good will narrow as the new cotton comes to market, but this will be by the new declining relative to old, not the old advancing relative to new, and a decline in new will continue to keep the trade on the better descriptions and keep them off the old. This is irrespective of the future course of the market as regards the size of the crop, and is based on the assumption that it will prove a fair average crop as regards quality.

There is a further condition, in that as this block of Continental futures is returned to the market as the contracts become exchanged for actual cotton on the other side, and has to be resold in competition with the surplus offers of hedges of such new cotton as may be bought by merchants who is there likely to come as actively to the point and buy them. This Continental business we have referred to has been practically supplied onto this crop although the yarn will be made out of the coming crop, thus unless the market can continue to keep the demand ahead of the year, the 1907-8 crop will not need to be as large by the amount of this forward business as is calculated, to fully supply all the demands even of the present bloated number of spindles. When this year's figures are made up we think it will be found that the world has put 1,000,000 bales to stock this season at the mills, or out of sight, and that the actual output of the spindles has been materially below the year's takings. Thus we reassert that the coming season will prove to be a ten months, and not a twelve months, year, and comparsons will prove of no value whatever.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN COMMAND.
div.p: Commenting upon the appointment of the Duke ot Connaught to the Mediterranean Command "Al Watan" says: —

"We were the first to note that the new Command created in a rather mysterious way for the Duke of Connaught implied a political significance of grave importance as far as Egypt was concerned. We believed the Royal Duke might think of making his head-quarters in Egypt, and quite a considerable namber of thinkers shared with us that opinion although nothing official has been forthcoming to confirm it so far. It appears now that our view of the new Command was adopted in certain official quarters here and elsewhere, for we have private intelligence of the reliable species that some of the highest personages feel perturbed and ill at ease in consequence of the novel departure in British policy. Whether the Duke of Connaught is ultimately to make his central office in this country or to make his visits to it more frequent and prolonged, he is sure to take precedence in matters of rank and prestige. Furthermore, it is only natural to presume that if Egypt is to rank with Malta and Gibralter—both British possessions of old—and to be under the constant superintendence of the King's brother, she cannot remain within the pale of Turkish suzerainty for any length ot time. No wonder, 'then, that the Porte looks askance at the new arrangement, or that the authorities in the Turkish capital seem alarmed as we were told by Reuter at the beginning of this week. Qfice again we suggest, although we have no authority for the suggestion, that the new Command is not an innocent creation and that Turkish rulers here and at Constantinople have ample reason for fear and calculation."

div.head:
NOTES FROM SANTA.
NEW NATIVE TRIBUNAL.

div.p: The Ministry of Justice has built a new native tribunal at Santa. It is in a good position, and of modern construction.

div.head: Two Cases of Murder.
div.p: A native from Tokh-maziad, Santa district, was fired at by an unseen person while attending a funeral. He was killed immediately, and the police are actively engaged in searching for the assassin. Another native from Kolaila was shot yesterday while standing before the gate of his house, and died almost immediately. Two persons were arrested who are said to be his enemies and with whom he had had disputes.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of the Khedive, was received in private audience by the Sultan at Yildiz Palace, during the past week.
Prince Mohamed Pasha Daoud has arrived at Alexandria from Europe.
Prince Omar, Pasha, Toussoun will arrive at Alexandria from Europe on Monday.
Prince Djemil Pasha, Toussoun has arrived at Paris fora short stay, after which he will return to Trouville.
Saad Pasha Zagloal, Minister of Public Instruction, is expected at Alexandria on the 16th prox.
Mr. P. P. Graves has returned to Cairo from Syria.
M. Olarowsky, the new Russian Commissioner to the Caisse de la Dette, has arrived at Alexandria.
Dr. S. Voronoff will sail to-day for Europe. He will visit the Tyrol and afterwards Paris, and return to Cairo at the end of October.
Dr. N. Arbeely, surgeon-dentist, returns to Cairo on Monday from his annual holiday, and resumes his usual hours of consultation at Maison Zahar, opposite Shepheard's hotel.

div.head: LITERARY TREASURE TROVE IN ANCIENT EGYPT.
div.p: Probably the oldest theological book in the world is the old Egyptian work known as "The book for the Dead," though if the similar series of writings, known as the "Pyramid Texts" because first discovered incised and emblazoned upon the interior of the 4th and 5th dynasty pyramids at Sakkara, belong to another work they may be still more ancient.

Vast as is the antiquity of the many chapters of "The book for the Dead," at the time when the first great collection of them we know of was arranged by the priests, numbering about 162 chapters, the work was already so old that some chapters had been lost or forgotten and consequently if such were ever discovered they had to be incorporated into the canon. Necessarily such an interpolation of an additional chapter would make all the specimen copies used by the scribes for engrossing these funerary writings for the many centuries during which the missing chapter had been omitted, imperfect, and therefore some particularly cogent reason had to be given for the insertion of the restored texts. This would be the more requisite if the freshly introduced matter had been so long lost sight of that the esoteric meaning was forgotten, and consequently although for pions reasons the priests decided it must be reinstated in the book yet its sentences were practically unintelligible.

Now Egyptologists find that the reason assigned for the restoration of chapters to "The book for the Dead" is always that they had been found again built into the walls or concealed in some part of a sacred edifice, and Professor Edouard Naville has recently in a lecture delivered at the "Society of Biblical Archeology" in London summed up the more important allegations as to the rediscovery of various ancient writings in Pharaonic Egypt. For instance, an interesting section of the "Book for the Dead" is called the "Chapter of the Heart." It gives words imagined to be spoken by the defunt to his heart when it is being weighed in the scales in the Judgment Hall. Now in several papyri of the "Book for the Dead," but notably in an 18th dynasty copy preserved at Parma, the following rubric to the Chapter is attached. "This chapter was found at Heliopolis on a brick (or slab) of the south (alabaster ?) under the feet of the Majesty of this venerable god, in the writing of the god himself, in the time of the Majesty of the King of Upper and Lower Egypt Menkaura. The royal son Hordudef found it when on his way to inspect the Egyptian temples.

Another papyrus states that the letters on the slab were engraved in pure lapis, and one adds that someone explained the contents to Hordudef and that he brought it to the King as something mysterious that no one living had ever looked at.

The meaning of this rubric is that in the Heliopolitan temple, which we know was sacred to Thoth, the god of literature and writing, this chapter, supposed to have been his special composition was, in case in the course of ages it should be lost, graven upon stone and hidden in the plinth, or base, of a statue ofthe deity, and there, when doubtless because of its decay or to protect the statue while the temple was being renovated the figure was removed, it was found as its original depositors hoped it {would be. As Menkaura was an early 4th dynasty Pharaoh, the era at which, before his time, the chapter had been hidden away, permitting: a sufficient period to elapse for its having been forgatten when we known that the sacred writings were almost as carefully cherished and preserved as by the Hebrews must be left to the imagination. The statue of Thoth would in the old temple of Heliopolis probably be in a small or most sacred chapel, or shrine, in the interior of the edifice, and it is possible that the adytum or most sacred enclosore of other temples, if they had therein a statue of the chief deity, would be found, if the base of the statue could now be recognised, to to have ancient texts engraved upon part of the stone.

JOSEPH OFFORD
(To be continued.)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "British Prince" with general cargo left Malta on the 30th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Tuesday.

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
STRONG ATTACK BY MOORS.

div.p: 4,000 Moors furiously attacked on the 28th. The French had 4 killed and several wounded. The Moors were repulsed with considerable losses. The following day was calm. Cannon dispersed some marauders. (Havas)
Baron Henri de Rothsehild has left for Casablanca with an ambulance. (Havas)

The garrison here has been ordered to Fez. The British Consulate has warned Britishers to proceed to specified places in the suburbs in case the town is attacked. The Europeans from Fez have arrived at Laraiche. They report that the Moors in the capital were clamouring for a holy war when they left. (R.)

The papers publish accounts of desperate fighting at Casablanca. The Moors attacked the town on 28th instant. They made a feint retreat and drew the French into an ambush. The French, being in a dangerous position, formed a square and kept off the Moors with the greatest difficulty till the arrival of artillery. Their casualties were 4 Algerians killed and 22 wounded. (Reuter)
In reply to the British demand for a warship the Foreign Office states that the French are sending another one here. (Reuter)

div.head:
TROUBLE IN IRELAND.
A MOONLIGHT ATTACK.

div.p: Armed moonlighters have attacked a house at Athenry : they fired into the windows : the police patrol returned the fire : no arrests have been made. (Reuter)

div.head:
COLLAPSE OF RAILWAY BRIDGE.
A WORKMEN KILLED.

div.p: 61 workmen have been killed owing to the collapse of a section, 1800 feet long, forming the centre span of a railway bridge in course of construction. (Reuter)
An engagement is announced between Prince George of Greece and Princesse Marie Bonaparte. (Havas)
Prince George is betrothed to Princess Marie Bonaparte. (Reuter)
An assembly hall has collapsed. Ten persons were killed. (Havas)
The committee of architects, appointed to examine the foundations of S. Paul's Cathedral owing to the alarming reports of instability, has issued a reassuring report. (Reuter)
The Sirdar who has been spending 2 months at Dunbar will return to the East at an early date. (Reuter)
The Sultan of Zanzibar has arrived here and proceeded to Marseilles en route for London. (Reuter)

A rise in the price of coal generally has heen announced, simultaneous with a 5 per cent increase in wages. This is due to the extraordinary demand for coal, especially abroad, and to the shortage of miners. (R.)

div.head:
NOTES FROM BEYROUT.
CONDITION OF CROPS.
A BAD SEASON.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: This year has been a rather bad one agriculturally for both Syria and Palestine. The average rainfall although good, was yet so untimely that the grain crops did not much benefit thereby. Indeed, in Southern Palestine they were an utter failure. Gaza, which in good years used to export alone, for Egypt and Europe, over 30,000 tons, mostly barley, has not this year wherewith to provide seed corn for the next crops, and the distress is said to be so great that some of the Bedonin tribes have had to migrate to neighboring districts in quest of living, and the scattering of these famished bands naturally addicted to predatory incursions determined such a state of insecurity that the local authorities have been refusing escorts to intending foreign travellers. In Jaffa although the dearth is not so marked, yet the produce in the way of grain is only a little in excess of the requirements of local consumption. It is hoped, however, that this deficiency will be partly compensated by a good orange crop which is estimated at a little over 800,000 cases. The sanguine estimators put the total at about a million.

In Acre and Caiffa districts the Goddess Ceres has been more merciful, and what should give an additional impetus to the trade movement at Caiffa itself is the Hejaaz Railway. The Director of the French Railway Company at Beyrout has himself confessed that not less than one third of the grain produce at Hauran and the outlying regions, destined for ultimate exportation, is being wrested from them by the Hejaaz Railway. It is alleged on the other hand that this has been possible only throngh disloyal competition and that to get round the barrier of the authorized tariff the weight of the train load has been under declared. A good deal of the general goods, such as apricot paste etc. destined for ultimate exportation from Damascus, been diverted to Caiffa, where the absence of onerous harbour dues sensibly reduces the charges. The same has been applying to a part of the imports for Damascus which, heretofore, has been coming through Beyrout, but which is now being ronted throngh Caiffa. Tne trade movement in Beyrout will, it is feared, prove this year less active. The staple prodact viz. barley, of Homs and Hama, is said to be below the average, both in regard to quality and quantity. The late rains have discolored the grain and rendered much of it unfit for malting purposes. But it is hoped that the extension to Aleppo will, by tapping that part ofthe Aleppo district traversed by the line, so increase the transport as to make up for the deficiency. A remarkable feature this year has been the unusual lateness of the harvest, and arrivals of grain from the interior have been at least a month later than last year.

As regards the Lebanon the high hopes that had been formed on the luxuriant growth of the mulberry tree have been dashed to the ground just at the last moment. A kind of beetle has wrought havoc among the silkworms, and old people declare having never seen such a scourge in their lives. A further disappointment was exporienced, also at the last moment, in the direction of prices which started with top figures and then at the full tide of the harvest dropped by several piastres per oke. The olive crop which also gave such a good promise at the outset, is causing same disillusion in several quarters, as the fruit ripens more and more into final size. To add to the list of misfortunes another little scourge has just been announced, in the shape of a caterpillar which is said to be causing damage to vegetation, such as potatoes maize etc. This, like the beetle scourge, is also unprecedented in agricultural annals in the Lebanon.

In Lattakia and district the bean crop, one of the chief resources of that region is said also to be even poorer than that of last year. Other grains also point to an unsatisfactory result, and as much may be said of the olive crop in that district. In Mersine and district fortunately the tardy rains seem to have had a desirable effect, and have, indeed, been the saving of the grain crops. Oats and barley have lately been shipping in fair quantities and further shipments for the Continent and the United Kingdom are yet to come. The cotton crop promises also gratifying results.

div.head: DIGGING UP PYRAMIDS.
div.p: In comparing some of the exploring expeditions which have made New York their starting point, several stratige and interesting contrasts offer themselves, yet in none is this more marked than in the one about to be undertaken by Commander Robert E. Peary in his search for the North Pole and that of the Metropolitan Museum expedition, which has just suspended operations until the return of cooler weather. Peary's search for the pole will be carried on in a climate where the mercury often crosses the mark at 75 degrees below zero, while the band of workers who are out in the interests of the Museum have been pursuing their labors where the thermometer reaches 130 degrees in the shade without seriously exerting itself.

The latter expedition, sent out under the direction of Albert M. Lythgee, was made possible through funds supplied by private generosity. A generous concession was granted to the Museum authorities by the Egyptian government, which, with a liberality not to be found in other ancient lands, has granted many liberties to foreign institutions for the purpose of scientific excavation and has permitted the exportation of a large share of sculptures and antiquities yielded by such work.

The labors of the American party are centred on the two pyramids of Lisht, near the southern end of the pyramid field, at a point thirty-five miles south of Cairo. Both of these date from the Middle Empire, about 2700 B.C., the northernmost having been identified as belonging to King Amenemhat I and the sothernmost as that of his son and successor, Usertesen 1. These two were kings of the twelfth dynasty, a time when art lacked a litlle of the vitality of earlier sculpture and yet in which some splendid works were turned out. The influence of Egypt was extended by these two to the lands on either side, and more and more information regarding this influence and the accomplishments of the kings of that dynasty has been discovered as the picks and spades of the workers slowly uncovered the ruins of the pyramid temple of Amenemhat, which was chosen for the first investigation, because a French expedition had previously excavated at the temple of Usertesen.

This work of unearthing an Egyptian temple is rather different from digging a tunnel or a city subway in Manhattan, for neither dynamite nor steam shovel may be ussd to facilitate the work. Such energetic methods have to be eliminated, as a jar or false blow might shatter a treasure which tells whole pages of history of an age when the world was still young. And so sand drifts and debris must be removed with the greatest care in order to preserve from demolition those relics which it is the object ot the workers to exhume and keep for the eyes of future generations, where in museums and private collections they may instruct those students who are putting together piecemeal the history of an age which in patt has been forgotten and lost.

Thus the work cautiously begun has been so continued. A railroad was built up to the base of the pyramid of Amenemlat and work begun along the east side, for it was on the side facing the Nile that the temple stood in which the worship of the King was perpetuated. The work of excavation began with the removal of drift sand and disintegrated limestone, which left a hard packed surface of debris. This was scattered over the side of the pyramid generally, beneath it beg house walls of brick and other remains which proved, from scarabs, beads and stnilar matetial found in them, to date from the Roman period, After photogtaphs were taken of the 'remains of Roman occupation, the labor was continued without interruption until recently the complete excavation of the pyramid temple was accomplished and the pritcipal external features of the pyramid on the eastern side were determlned.

Thus far in the work of clearing back to the face of the pyramid itself important material has been recovered which will make a distinct contribution to the history of Egyptian architecture and art during this period of the Middle Empire. From relics found it is probable that this temple was reconstructed from an earlier one, though the facts and the date ot this may be more easily ascertained when the excavations have been carried further along. In this temple site, however, has been found a considerable amount of material from the ornal temple of Amenetmbat, from which the main features of the structute may be determined. There are mary interesting fragments and complete blocks of painted relief and of inscriptions. One of the scenes on the temple depicts Amenemhat receiving the gift of the gods. This relief is delicately and most beautifully modelled, and in many part has its color still freshly preserved. At the rear end of the temple two most important subjects were found, one being a granite temple altar, or offering table, and the other offering stela of the temple. The stela is the only one of its kind that has been found, and is therefore of importance.

While these excavations and discoveries have been going on in the pyramid temple considerable work has been carried on in the cemetery west of the pyramid. The tombs are proved to be of important twelth dynasty types, both in their construction and in the character in their contents, and their excavation has been an important factor in the satisfactory result of the year.

Through this work which is now going on in Egypt the recently established department of Egyptian art of the Museum will be enriched by many of the relics from the tombs and temples of these kings of ages past, and as all of the really fine things from the soil of Egypt are being rapidly absorbed by the great public collections the Metroplitem considers itself especially fortunate at this time in being enabled to enter the field so actively and get its share of Egyptian treasure. ("New York Daily Tribune")

div.head:
LITERARY TREASURES AND SCARCE MSS.
REMARKABLE PRICES.
div.p: This year's season at Sotheby's, Wellingtonstreet, Strand, recently bronght to a close, was remarkable for the great prices realised for rare and exceptional books and very scarce manuscripts.

One of the prominent sales was that of Mr. William Van Antwerp, of New York, which was not a library, but an extraordinary collection of the rarest editions of classical English writers, from Chaucer to Tennyson, including the four first folios and ten original quarto plays of Shakespeare. The first folio fetched the high figure of £8,600, and the third folio £650, both being secured by Mr. Quaritch. Among the quartos King Lear went for £200, and the Rape of Lucrece for £350. Among other gems in the New York assemblage were the original Kilmarnock Robert Burns, £700, the other two of equal excellence are the Lamb copy; tow in a private library at New York, which cost £572 5s., and the other in the Burns' Cottage Museum at Ayr, for which the trustees paid £1,000. The Caxton Cicero "On Old Age and Friendship," printed in 1481, £600; Foxe's Book of Martyrs, £80; W. Hubhard's Narrative ofthe Troubles with the Indians in New England, £450; the first Prayer-book of Edward VI., £100; Parchas his Pilgrimes, a superb copy, £170; Sir Walter Scott's Waverley Novels, original editions, £300; Sir Philip Sidney's The Countesse of Pembroke's Arcadia, £315 ; and Izaak Walton's he Compleat Angler, one of the finest of the first editions, £1,290 (Quaritch).

In other sales the First Folio Shakespeare went for £680, £2,400, and £135 ; the Second Folio, £220, £230, and £140; the Third Folio, £130, £205, £800, and £1,550, a record price ; and the Fourth Folio, £72, £86, and £80. A rare copy of Shakespeare's Sonnets reached no less than £800. Some manuscripts of Burns, including "Seots wha hae wi' Wallace bled," sold for £355; six autograph MSS., with "Hear, Land o'Cakes and brither Scots" among them, £365; and five poems and letters, "O, Kenmore's on and awa', Willie," "The Brigs of Ayr," £350.

Selecting a few and most striking of the rest of the books of the season, we must mention the following :—Goldsmith's 'The Traveller," £216 ; the first edition of Gray's "Elegy," £205 ; the first part of the "Conten- tion betwixt the two famous Houses of Yorke and Lancaster," 1594, the foundation play of Shakespeare's "Henry VI, Part II., £1,910; the doubtful "Arden of Faversham," £1,210 ; "The Three Voyages of Sir Martin Frobisher," £2,680 ; "The White Ship" and a "Sonnet on S.T. Coleridge," £105; Oliver Goldsmith's "The Vicar of Wakefield,' first edition, £100, a number of first editions of Dickens's works fetched good prices, that of "Bleak House" realising £99 ; it was a presentation copy to his daughters.

Autographs and manuscpripts were much to the fore, astonishing prices being paid. The original autograph MS. of Robert Burns's "The Poet's Progress," fetched £152 ; a number of lettersof Dr. Johnson to Mrs. Thrale, all in one lot, went for £240 ; the Massdore. of Glen- coe," original order to Capt.' Robert Campbéll to exterminate the Clan McDonald, £1,400 (Tregaskis); thirty-four lettérs of Benjamin' Disraeli to his sister Sarah, and his original MS. of his Speech in the: Hotse of Comrmotis on the:death of the Duke of Wellington, £101 ; proof sheets of various portiotis of Byron's works and part of his M8: of "Childe Harold," £174; Charles Lamb's "Dream Children," £408 ; Alexander Pope's "The Essay on Man," £895 (Sabin) ; Pope's "Of Taste," an epistle to the Earl of Burlington, £199; Tennyson's "The Brook," £300; The Northern Farmer, with many corrections, £155; Thackeray's Draft of Chapters 4 and 5 of "Philip," £240 ; Gilbert White's "Selborne," £750 (Harford) ; Handel's Score of the "Messiah" in the hand. writing of J. Christopher Smith, his friend, and amanuensis, £100; Sir Walter Scott's "The History of Scotland," £510; and Thackeray's MB. of "Essay on George II.," with corrections in his autograph, £81.

div.head: A VERY FAST STORY.
div.p: An Englishman was bragging of the speed on English railroads to a Yankee traveller eated at his side in one of the cars of a "fast train" in England. The engine bell was rung as the train neared a station. It suggested to the Yankee an opportunity of "taking down his compatiion a peg or two."
"What's that noise?" innocently inquired he Yankee.

"We are approaching a town," said the englishman. "They have to commence ringing about ten miles before they get to a station, or else the train would run by it before the bell could be heard! Wonderful, isn't it?" I suppose they haven't inverted bells in America yet?"

"Why, yes," replied the Yankee. "We've got bells, but can't use them on our railroads. We run so tarnal fast that the train always keeps ahead of the sound. No use whatever; the sound never reaches the village till the train gets by."
"Indeed," exclaimed the Englishman.

"Fact," said the Yankee. "Had-to give up bells. Then we tried steam whistles, but they wouldn't answer either. I was on a locomotive when the whistle was tried. We were going at a tremendous rate—hurricanes were nowhar, and I had to hold me hair on. We saw a two horse wagon crossing the track, about five miles ahead, and the engineer let the whistle on, screeching like a trooper. It screamed awfully, but it wasn't no use. The next thing knew I was picking myself out of a pond by the roadside, amid the fragments of the locomotive, dead horses, broken wagons, dead engineer lying beside me. Just then the whistle came, mixed up with some frightful oaths that I had heard the engineer use when he first saw the horses. Poor fellow he was dead before his voice got to him. After that we tried lights, supposing these would travel taster than sound. Ye got some so powerful that the chickens woke up all along the road when we came by supposing it to be morning. But the locomotive kept ahead of it still, and was in darkness, with the light close on behind it. The inhabitants petitioned against it ; they couldn't sleep with so much light in the night time. Finally, we had to station electric telegraphs along the road, with signalmen to telegraph when the train was in sight ; and have heard that some of the fast trains beat the lightning 15 minutes every 40 miles. But I can't say as that is true-the rest I know to be so."

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton.

La tenue de notre marché aux contrats,pen- dant ces derniers sept jours, a été sans con- tredit bien meilleure que celle que nous avons eue potir les deux on trois semaines précéden- tes ; mais, point regrettable 4 relever, tout ce mieux, qui, &un moment donnéd, avait com- mencé peut-étre 4 faire miroiter aux yeux des intéressés Tillusion d'une réussite, se trouve réduit & un peu plus d'affaires, grice aux ten- tatives de manceuvres spéculatives de quelques haussiers, fatigués de rester dans l'oisiveté pen- dant si longtemps. Quant an fond de la sitna- tion, il n'a nullement changé, et nous n'en voulons pour preuve que le prompt retour a l'état primitif, dés qu'il a semblé & notre cor- beille qu'il y avait arrét dans le mouvement de hausse des américains. Mais, ne nous laissons pas entrainer par nos réflexions, et procédons par ordre dans notre revue, La premitre séance, celle tle Samedi, n'a rien eu d'extraordinaire, la petite avance de 1/32 enregistrée en cléture ne montrant, apres tout, qu'un peu de fermeté, pour rareté de vendeurs pent-étre, mais qui n'en a pas moins été considérée comme snffisamment encoura- geante pour stimuler quelques détenteurs de contrats 4 entreprendre une manipulation haus- siére, bien entendu. Et de fait, pendant les trois matinées qui ont suivi, cette fermeté n'a fait que s'accentuer pour finir par se résumer en une hausse de 5/16 de tallari, ce qui, malgré tout, ne constitue pas un résultat & dédaigner ; mois si, pour y arriver, il a fallu 4 nos haussieurs quatre jours de cris et defforts, il nous a suffi. par contre d'une heure de temps pour perdre 7/32, sans qu'il y ait eu le moindre fait sérienx pouvant justifier ce recul si rapide et si sensible. Tel a été le cas hier ; mais ce qui a été plus mauvais encore, c'est qu'aujourd'hui nous avons perdu 3/32 de plus, revenant, de la sorte, & notre point de-départ, soit & la cote de 20 5/16 de Vendredi dernier. Nous ne voulons pas exagérer la signification ou la portée de pareils faits, mais on nous coneédera, nous l'espérons du moins, qu'ils sont loin d'étre lindice d'une situation bonne ou saine. Et sans étre doné d'une bonne dose d'optimisme irréfléchi, on ne sanrait guére non plus prétendre que le marché se maintient bien, car tandis que nous perdons si facilement. toute l'avance, |'Américain, qui nons a tourni le prétexte pour la manupulation dont il a été question, est resté, lui, gagnant de plus de 20 points 4 Liverpool. C'est tout dire. Notre place souffre d'un mal local, pour l'appeler ainsi, et c'est de la question moné- taire et tant qail n'y aura pas en d'améliora- tion réelle de ce cdté-la, toutes les mancuvres sont prématurées et vouées & un échee certain, d'autant plus que la filature, sous l'influence des avis qu'elle regoit sur notre récolte, con- tinue 4 ne nous fournir aucun appui. Certes, elle achete tout ce qu'on lui offre en vieille récolte, mais pour ce qui est de la non- velle sa réserve est compléte et en cela elle n'a pas tort, car rien ne presse avec les perspectives en vue. Elle ne tardera sfiirement pas 4 se mettre aux achats, mais dans |l'entre-temps, on sera aussi fixé sur la récolte, et si celle-ci donne les résultats espérés, elle saura régler ses opéra- tions de facon 4 pouvoir profiter des circonsfan ces favorables qui se présenteront A elle. Lundi prochain, trés probablement 1' Alexandria General Produce Association nous donnera son résumé pour le mois d'Aoft qui ne pourra étre des plus rassurants & en jugerparles premi: res réponses qu'elle vient de recevoir de lintérieur. Tous ses correspondants sont d'ac- cord pour afhrmer que ni les vers, ni les bronillards n'ont fait aucun mal jusqu'ici et que si nous n'en avons pas fini avec cerisque, il n'en est pas moins vrai que quelques jours de plus du temps qui régne suffiraient pour nous assurer la premiére, et peut-Ctre méme la seconde cueillette dans la Basse-Kgypte. Dars tous les eas, les choses semblent tellement avancées, que dict une dizaine de jours on eommencera 4 cueillir un pen partont dans le Delta. Dans la Haute-Egypte, la cueillette bat son plein et les arrivages promettent un dévelop- pement rapide sons peu de jours. En attendant, le coton recu pendant la se- maine de Bibeh et de Beni-Souef ne s'est. pas vendu trés facilement: les acheteurs ne mon- trent. pas de dispositions bien chandes et aprés 20 1/4 et 20 1/8, Ona df finir par céder a 19 3/4, et cela malgré la belle qualité de ce qui était offert a la vente. A ce propos, nous ajouterons que cette cir- constance n'a peut-étre pas été étrangére A la faiblesse des contrats. Pour ce qui est de l'intérieur, les cultivateurs, pressés par leurs besoins pécuniaires, se mon- trent trés enclins 4 vendre, mais ce sont les acheteurs qui se font prier: Soit qu'ils crai- «nent la prolongation de la crise monétaire, soit. qu'ils agissent avec l'idée de profiter de la situation, le fait est qu'ils ne sont pas faciles a se départir de leur argent et qu'ils n'opérent que d'une facgon trés modérée Du cété de | Amérique, comme cela est gé- néralement le cas, les nouvelles sont contra- dictoires, mais en attendant c'est la fermeté qui prédomine. Le point pour le moins curieux A relever, est le peu de cas que Liverpool, ou pour mieux dire, les maisons sérieuses de la dite place font des avis de dégats & la récolte. Ony raisonne la question et on arrive a la conclusion qu'é moins de maux futurs, la ré- colte sera quand méme supérieure 4 tous les besoins possibles de la consommation. Dans quelques jours, nous aurons aussi le Rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture. I] est cer- tain qu'on n'y fera pas attention, mais s'il ne s'écarte pas trop de ce que diront les autres autorités 'en la matiére, il pourra quand méme étre utile avec ses renseignements.Notre marché du disponible a été d'un calme parfait et sans les qnelques' lots de doton nou- veau qui lui ont donné un peu de vie, il y aurait eu pour ainsi dire nullité complate (affaires, Quant 4 la cote, elle n'a pas été modifiée pour le Mit Afifi, mais en réalité les détenteurs des rares lots restant 4 réaliser se montrent intraitables et celui qui a besoin de quelques balles doit dépasser les cours officiels pour faire son affaire. Le coton Haute-Egypte, nouveau produit, est coté 4 20 tallaris pour le Good. Toutefois, le cours pratiqué aprés l'établissement de la cote de ce matin n'est que de 19 3/4. Les exportations de la semaine ont dépassé torte attente avec leur total de 5630 balles, contre 2200 Balles l'année derniére, et une bonne part. de l'augmentation inattendue sem- ble provenir de nouvelles affaires qui se font tous les jours, C'est du reste a cette circonstance que l'on doit que Von ne sanrait faire de pronostics pour la semaine prochaine. I] y a des engage- nents sur Septembre, mais on ignore la répar- tition des embarquements ; mais ce qui est le plus important, c'est que presque tout notre stock est placé a I'étranger et d'ici deux ov trois jours, on en connaitra l'importance, la révision annuelle de la Produce Association devant étre publiée Lundi ou Mardi prochain. Tout. ce qui a été dit dans les journanx & ce propos, quoique pouvant étre vrai, n'a aucon caractére officiel, ni officieux. Liverpool a annoncé dans l'ensemble des ventes assez rondes en Egyptiens disponibles, mais pource qui est des cours du spot, toute l'amélioration consiste dans le retour de la cote 4 10 3/4, soit 1/16 de reprise. Les futurs par contre l'inscrivent en hausse de 11/64 pour l'Aoft qui vaut 1041/64 A la cloture de ce soir. Les américains disponibles ont été anssi assez actifs et les cours ont largement profité de cette tenue en finissant ce soir 4 7 49 pour le spot, &8 6.81 pour l'Octobre-Novembre et A 6.72 pour le Janvier-Février, ce qui fait res- pectivement 22, 22 et 19 points de hausse.
Graines de Coton

Les arrivages de la semaine ont eu une certaine importance, mais comme la vieille graine recue n'était pas destinée au marché, les affaires en disponible se sont tronvées foreément limitées aux quelques lotins de Graine Haute-Egypte nouvelle récolte qui ont été mis en vente. — Le prix pratiqués contrats, il n'y a en que tres pen d'affaires, mais avec la rareté des vendeurs la cote est restée trés ferme en définitive. Elle a toutefois varié, allant jusqu'a P.T. 73 5/40 pour réactionner a P.T. 70 1/2 presque sans désemparer et finir & P.T. 71 3/4 pour les 3 mois. Hull, de £7 17/6, était monté 4 £8 7/6 pour l'Aoft et pour sir il doit y avoir en quelque découvert retardataire A lhiquider. Aujourd'bui la cote n'est plus que de £8 5/-. Quant a la nouvelle récolte, elle se main tient assez bien & £7 3/9 ponr les trois mois Novembre-Janvier.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le marché a ouvert lundi avec beaucoup d'animation pour se calmer assez vite et finir terne. Seuls quelques titres d'ordre secondaire, en particulier la Delta Land et les Estates, ont donné lien 4 quelqne mouvement, les autres étant totalement délaissés. On concoit aisé- ment que dans de telles conditions la cote n'ait pas eu d'écarts bien sensibles. Cet état de marasme devait ¢tre de courte durée. Dés le lendemain, Londres nous étant arrivé en hausse pour les valeurs égyptiennes et en baisse pour Je tanx privé d'escompte, la fermeté a repris le dessus et les cours ont béné- ficié d'une avance que des réalisations subsé- qnentes ont malheurensement enrayée. La spécnlation s'est résolument reportée sur les valeurs dirigeantes au d"triment de celles de moimndre envergure, parmi lesquelles la Delta Land et les Ritz ont conservé seules un peu de vogue. Mercredi le taux privé d'escompte ayant en- core ¢té réduit et les valeurs locales étant ve- nues en nouvelle hausse, lindécision de nos spéculatenrs a de nonvean fait place a une remarquable assurance, Plus de vendeurs et Yardenr des acheteurs était telle qu'on avait Villusion d'assister 4 une séance d'hiver. Les titres dirigeants, activés par une demande provenant d'Europe, étaient l'ohjet de l'atten- tion générale. On en déduirait volontiers que ce jour-la d'énormes paquets de titres ont changé de mains. I] n'en arien été, cependant ; & part quelques affaires en Agricole, le reste ne vaut pas la peine d'étre mentionné. Tout ce beau zéle n'a dailleurs été qu'un feu de paille. Hier les vendeurs ayant de nou- veau déyoilé leurs positions, il en est résulté comme d'ordinaire une abstention & pen prés compléte des acheteurs. Les échanges se sont limités, en proportions d'ailleurs minimes, aux Agricole, National Bank, Delta Land et Hooker. Quelques Levico et Lunghis ont aussi été vendues aux enchéres publiques. Ce matin enfin, comme un digne couronne- ment de la semaine, la corbeille, en dépit d'nne apparence animée qu'elle avait prise au début, est tombée dansun matasme 4 peu prés com- plet. Le résultat est que la cote demeure au méme niveau que Vendredi passé, les valeurs en hausse étant d'unnombreégal & cellesen baisse. Si l'on ajoute que laplupart de ces fluctuations n'ont que peu d'importance, on arrive a la conclusion qne la semaine écoulée a été l'une des moins intéressantes dela saison et que c'est sans doute a l'excellente tenue de nos valeurs sur les marchés européens qu'il faut attribuer le soutien relatif dont la cote a bén- ficié ici. | Parmi les chatigeitients les 'plus notables il faut signaler uné progression dé'3/16 sur |' Agri- cole 4 8 3/16, de1/4 sur la National Bank, l'Alexandria Water et la Daira aux cours res- pectifs. de 20 1/4,:11 1/2 et.12 1/2, de 4 fr. sur la Cassa di Sconto 4 42, de- 3.16 sur la Land Bank 4 7 3/16, de 5/16 sur'les Splendid Hotels a 45/16, de 3/16 sur l'Union Fonciére a 4 11/16; un fidchissement de 1/8 surla Delta Light et |'Urbaine & 9 5,16 et 3 9/16, de 1/4 sur la part de fondateur Comptoir a 2 1/2 et de 1/4 sur la fondateur United a 2. En baisse également les Markets de 27/6 a 27, PObligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 257 A 255, la Bangtté d'Athénés de 1114 110 1/2, Ordinary Khedivial Mail dé 22/6 a 21/3, le Comptoir de 2 11/16 A 2 19/32, le Banco di Roma de 105 4 104, ' Aboukir de 28 & 27/6, la fondateur 'Allotment de 70 4°65, la Port Said Salt 'dé 14/6 4 14, PHeloadn de 9/32 A 7/32, et la Levico de 7/16 a 3/8. Les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie ont avancé, an contraire, de 295 4.298, les Divi- dendes Biére du Caire de 40 4 42, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 300 a 302, les Lots Tures de'158 4 159, l'Investmént de 1/2 4 17/32, les Estates de 21/32 & 11/16, la Ban- que d'Orient de 114 4 117, et Allotment de. 2 3/8 a2 1/2. A Londres et a Paris les valeurs égyptien- | nes ont été en général fermes ; plusiéirs méme | ont bénéficié dune plus-value : la Daira et la National Bank ont gagné 1'4 4.12 1/2 et 20 1/4, l'Agricole 1/8& 8 1/4, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien 1 fr. 4685 et la Land Bank 4 fr. 4 186. Seule la Banque d'Athénes est revenue de 112 a 111 et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 108.50 a 108. Le Consolidé Anglais est' re- monté de 82 4 82 3/4 et la Rente Francaise de 94.20 & 94.52. Grace au maintien de son taux officiel & 4 1/2 %, alors que le taux privé était tombé de 4 7/8 & 4 3/8 7%, la Banque d'Angleterre a vu augmenter sa réserve de 48 1/4 4 49 3/8 %. Si lon consid re qu'on redoutait naguére |'obliga- tion pour cette banque de porter son taux officiel 4 5% en présénce d'une demafde d'or trés active, on se rendra compte combien cette détente monétaire inattendue a sonlagé le marché. Décidément on avait vu plus noir que de raison. Voici ce qu'écrit le Statist 4 ce sujet : '"Emprunteurs et préteurs savent, cette année, de bonne leure, que la Banque d' Angleterre nest pas en état d'exporter de l'or, excepté pour deux ou trois psys qui penvent le lui demander en raison de leur balance commefciale favorable. Ces contrées sont I'Egypte, le Brésil et l'Argentine. Dans les quatre derniers mois, malgré la tension de notre marché monétaire, nous avons en- voyé 6,135,000 livres sterling d'or en Egypte, 4,054,000 liv. st. dor au Brésil et 880,000 liv. st. & l'Argentine. D'ici a la fin de l'année, nos banquiers estiment que nous aurons encore a envoyer 6.000.000 de livres sterling d'or en Egypte et un montant considérable dans l'Amériqne du Std, particuliérement aun Brésil, Londres sera capable de faire face 4 ces demandes, pourvu que les Etats-Unis ne viennent pas diminuer ses provisions. L'année derniére, nos expéditions d'or aux Ktats-Unis s'élevérent, en septembre, a 7,171,000 liv. st. Ces chargements, ajoutés aux montants adressés au Brésil, 4 l'Egypte et a VArgentine, nouns firent perdre plus de 16,000,000 de livres st. d'or dans le quatre derniers mois de l'année. Cette de- mande était hors de nos moyens et, fort heureusement, la Bangue de France vint A notre aide." De tous cdtés on discute sur la crise moné- taire et le retentissement éventuel qu'elle pourrait avoir sur la prochaine saison. Il y a tant de ciiconstances en jeu qu'il est bien difficile d'en tirer une conclusion précise. Con- tentons-nous de dire que l'horizon s'est un peu éclairci et que la réduction du taox privé d'es- coinpte de 4 7/84 4 3/8 % semble démontrer qu'on avait exagéré le péril, du moins immé- diat. Voici que le Statist assure que |'Angle- terre pourra suftire aux besoins de la récolte égyptienne, mais 4 condition que l'Amérique n'entame pas ses ressources. En admettant que cette condition sont remplie, il restera a pourvoir aux besoins de notre marché financier qui a pris depuis deux ou trois ans une exten- sion dispoportionnée avec ses moyens.Et c'est précisément la question. Est-ce que les ban- ques locales pourront enfin avancer réguliére- ment sur les titres et 4 quel taux? La réside le no-ud de la question pour l'avenir de nos valeurs. Il est bien certain que le capitaliste ou le spé- culateur, avant de garnir son portefeuille de paquets de titres, compare auparavant lintérét qu'il devra payer & la banque avec la plus-va- lue probable de ses titres, et dans le'cas de for- tes sommes il examine s'il n'a pas dans le pays méme des placements plus sfirs et a la fois plus avantageux. La réside le probléme et pas ailleurs. L'argent disponible va toujours au meilleur placement. Or qui ne sait que grice ala crise les capitalistes locaux ont trouvé & placer derniérement leurs disponibilités a des taux qui paraitraient invraisemblables en Eu- rope et moyennant des garanties de sécurité absolues ? Tous ces capitaux, affectés en partie a des reports les années précédentes, sont mon- mentanément perdus pour la spéculation, et cest peut-étre ce qui va paralyser pour un temps le marché a terme qu'on parle de ré- tablir. Cela ne veut pas dire qu'il faille s'y opposer. A la condition d'étre soignéisement régle- menté pour prévenir de notiveanx abbé, il ne peut que contribuer 4 redonner a notre marché un peu de vie. Aussi attend-on avec impa- tience le rétablissement annoncé ponrle ler Septembre par la Corporation des agents de change de la Capitale. Sans aucun doute, l'exemple du Caire sera immédiatément suivi par Alexandrie et dans le cas ot la'réglementa- tion élaborée donnerait toute satisfaction, elle sera également adoptée par |'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie. (est du moins ce que fait supposer l'union étroite des deux places qui ne permettrait. gnére a l'une d'elles d'avoir un organisme étranger a l'autre. Aprés avoir été longtemps délaissée, la Sidi Salem s'impose de nonvean a l'attention, Elle vient de conclure coup sur coup trois ventes de terrains, dont 150 feddans & raison de 60 livres le feddan, 7 a raison de 100 livres et 13 Araison de 120 livres. A la suite de ces trois opérations elle a été l'objet de demandes en bourse d 2 1/4, mais sans affaires. Les administrateurs de la Bourse and Ban- king (Arditi), qui ont obtenu de |'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie une série de mesures d'exception au détriment des ac- tionnaires et cela dans le but, disait-on, de prévenir un dépdt de bilan, ont découvert naguére qu'en dépit de ces faveurs la société ne pouvait aller de l'avant ; ce qui n'est que trop vrai: ainsi, !a Banque de Salonique, eréanciére de la Bourse and Banking d'un effet de 6000 livres, resté impayé, est surle point (si elle ne l'a déja fait) d'assigner cette dernisre en état de faillite. A l'assemblée d'hier soir, convoquée dans le but de délibérer sur la liquidation volontaire de la société, le quorum statutaire n'ayant pas été atteint, une nouvelle convocation a été faite pour le 5 septembre prochain. Cette nouvelle réunion; qui sera valable, quel que soit le nombre des actions représentées, promet d'étre fort intéressante. Les actionnaires obtiendront enfin, il faut lespérer, quelques explications sur |'étonnante gestion de leurs affaires, le retard dans la livraison des titres, la décision obtenue de Association de ne régler que certaines diffé- rences, le refus de livrer les titres aux action- naires sans que ceux-ci aient signé au préalable une espéce de formule d'abdication de leurs droits, enfin la liquidation de la société aprés qu'ils avaient dérangé tout le monde sous prétexte d'éviter cette éventualité.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Vendredi 30 Aout.

Le taux de l'escompte libre hier 4 Londres s'est maintenu a 4 3/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8A 82 5/8. L'Unifide est restée invariée 4 100 1/2. Le National Bank s'est tassée de 1/8 & 20 1/4, de méme que |'Agricole 48 1/2. La Delta Light a été sontenue A 9 1/2. La Daira a rétrogradé de 1/8 a 12 1/2. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 1 franc 3 686 et la Banque d'Athénes 2 franes 4112. Les Lots tures ont fiéchi de 1 frane A 164. * " loi, le marché a montré anjourd'hni un pen dessoufiement et les affaires ont ¢té res treintes. Malgré cette mauvaise humeur passagére les cours ont conservé une fermeté trés accnsée et telles valeurs parmi les plus traitées, qui avaient a un certain moment passablement rétrogradé, ont regagné quelques points en cloture. A bien voir Jes choses, il faut noter 4 l'actif du marché un certain progrés sur l'allure WVhier. Dans lecompartiment des Banques, la National Bank reste invari¢e 4 20 1/4. L' Agricole se raffermit 4 8 3/16. La Cassa di Sconto se reléve a 42-43 et les fondateurs Société Générale tombent a 37. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire paraissent mieux disposées & 203. La Daira Sanieh progresse 4 12 9/16. Le Crédit Foncier remonte & 681-682, tandis que obligation nouvelle est ramenée & 256. La Béhéra recule 4 20 1/4 et obligation reste 4 4 1/4 (nominal).L'Allotment toujaurs active se consolide 4 27/16-1/2. Les Entreprises Immobiliéres et Travaux trés attaquées reviennent 4 21,2; leur part est demandée 4 P.T. 48. Les Héliopolis fléchissent & 246. Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Baehler bien que mouvementés s'inscrivent légérement faibles A 6 1/16. L'Upper Egypt mollit 4 2 13/16. Les National Hotels sont moins soutenus 4 2 5/8, au contraire de leur part qui reste a P.T. 32. Parmi les petites valeurs, Ja Delta Land est parmi les plus traitées 4 1 7/8. La New Egyptian s'alourdit & 14/6-9. Les Abdy retombent & 0 1/2 et les Hooker progressent 40 1/2. La fondateur Express Nile Steamers est en meilleure tendance & P.T. 49 et la deferred Excelsior Hotels tombe 4 0 7/16. = as Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les sa medis pendant la saison d'été et le Comité ayant décidé qu'il y aurait cessation d'affaires lundi 2 Septembre, le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire ne paraltra que le mardi 3 Septembre courant. 2 # # Parlant-de la situation monétaire actuelle et supputant les chances d'une prochaine dé. tente, & laquelle il croit sans vouloir rien affirmer, 'The Economist" termine par les réflexions suivantes : 'La demande de !'Egypte ne parait pas devoir étre inférieure acelle del'an dernier ; nous avons indiqué plus haut les raisons, 4 savoir le désir des Banques en Egypte de se tenir bien munies de numéraire, comme conséquences de la crise. L'Allemagne, qui a ses embarras industriels, pourra demander un peu d'aide, mais en somme le neeud de la situation est aux Etats-Unis. "Evidemment, en Europe, on n'a pas reporté les valeurs américaines ni accepté du papier financier américain, 4 beaucoup prés dans la méme proportion que l'an dernier. Donc, de ce chef, les Etats-Unis n'auraient pas le méme pouvoir. de retirer de l'or. Par contre, l'Europe n'usant pas de complaisance 4 leur égard, i] est possible qu'ils n'aient pas 4 l'égard de l'Europe les mémes ménagements que l'an dernier et qu'ils prennent brutalement tout lor auquel une balance de commerce favorable peut leur donner droit. "Dans de semblables conditions, il est bien entendu qu'il n'y a pas & prophétiser. On a pris beaucoup de précautions et il est possible que tout se passe pour le mieux 4 l'automne. Par contre, il est également possible qu'avant de voir lecommerce se restreindre et amener, une détente monétaire, on traverse une phase de préoccupations monétaires plus ou moins vive", Pa On nous écrit d'Alexandrie & la date d'hier : "Demain aura lien l'assemblée générale-de la Bourse and Banking, convoquée d'aprés l'avis péru dans les journaux, aux fins de décider la liquidation volontaire de la Société et, le cas échéant, désigner les liquidateurs, ~ Selon les bruits qui courent, les administra- teurs auraient dit se résigner 4 cette éventnalité devant l'impossibilité de continuer les affaires en raison des engagements auxquels i] est impossible de satisfaire. On dit aussi que l'on espére éviter ainsi une déclaration de faillite qui serait prochainement demandée par une banque créanciére pour une somme assez importante. * * & Carnet de l'actionnaire. MM. les actionnaires de la H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd, sont informés qne par délibération du consei]l d'administration, il a été décidé de faire l'appel du 4me et dernier versement le ler Septembre 1907. Les versements devront é¢tre effectués aux guichets de la Société, rue Kasr-el-Nil au Caire, Aux termes del'art. 18 des Statuts, tonte somme non payée le jour de son exigibilité porte intéréts de plein droit en faveur de la Société au taux de 9 Y Ian. — MM. les actionnaires de 'he Commercial and Estates Cy. of Egypt, sont convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire, aui aura lieu le samedi 14 Septembre & 10 heures a.m., au siége social & Alexandrie. A Vordre du jour: Ratification de certains actes (lu conseil d'administration. Les actions devront étre déposées au sige social trois jours avant la réunion.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de confection et de canalisation du pro- longement de la Rue Sultan Selim a Ras el Tin. Le cautionnement est fixé & LE 500. Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique oh il peutétre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h. 4 midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront étre adressées sous pli caoheté A Monsieur |'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 10 Septembre 1907. Elles pourront également étre déposées en séance de la Délégation le méme jour 4 5 h. p.m, L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men- tion : 'Soumission pour Travaux de confec- tion et de canalisation du prolongement de la rue Sultan Selim a4 Ras-el-Tin." Le cautionnement ou le regu d'une banque, d'aprés les conditions du cahier des charges, devra étre remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 10 Septembre 1907 a midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée, Le Vice-Président, (Signé) Dr. Schiess, Alexandrie, le 26 Aout 1907. 80844-3-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le 3 Septembre 1907 de9h.am. 4 1 h. p.m. la Municipalitée procédera & la vente aux enchéres publiques prés du Fort (Port Rosette) d'ane quantité de 10000 m3 environ de pierres provenant de la dite démolition, ainsi que d'une quantité de fenétres, vieux bois. Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 2 a 100 m3. Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en- chére de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valeurde la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de |'adjudica- tion. Ilsauront 4 supporter les droits de carriére au profit lela V1 le et devront enlever les pierres achetées dansun délai de Dix (10) jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de Vadjudicataire et sous perte du dépit de 10 %, La Municipalité est libre dene pas donner suite Aladjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts, Alexandrie, le 27 Aout 1907. Le Vice-Président, 30845-3-1 (Signé) Dr. Schiess.

div.head:
Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
NOTICE.
div.p: The Administration has the honour to inform the Fublic that tenders will be received up to noon on Thursday, 10th October next, for the supply of Carriage Trimmings in strict accordance with the Administration's standard Samples which may be inspected at the Central Stores at Boulac (Cairo) and at Gabbary Stores (Alexandria), where a complete set may be obtained at the price of L.E. 0.800 (eight hundred milliemes). A Copy of the specification and lists relating to these supplies can also be obtained at the above addresses on payment of L.E. 0.200 (two hundred milliemes).

All persons desiring to take part in this adjudication must first lodge with the Central Treasury of the Administration at Cairo a sum of L.E. 25 (Twenty five Egyptian pounds) as a provisional guarantee and the successful tenderer will be required to increase this sum to the amount of ten per cent of his accepted offer.
Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of the value of thirty milliemes and be addressed by registered post to:-
The General Manager, Egyptian State Railways, Cairo.
under double envelope, the inner bearing the following inscription:—
"Offer for Carriage Trimmings." The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any offer, and reserves to itself the right of dividing the order.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration a Phonneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au lundi, trente Septembre prochain & midi au plus tard des offres pour la fourniture de dix huit millions de cartes non imprimées pour billets de Chemins de fer, suivant la liste, les échantillons et le Cahier des Charges dont un exemplaire sera mis 4 la disposition des inté- ressés sur leur demande au Buresu de Mr. VInspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary & Alexandrie et 4 celu. de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux A Boulac (Caire) contre paiement de cent milliéines. Toute personne désirant prendre part 4 cette adjudication devra verser en méme temps qu'elle présente son offre, 4 la Caisse Centrale de] Administration au Caire, one somme de vingt Livres Egyptiennes a titre de caution- nement provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire aura 4 patfaire cette somme jus- qu'a concurrence du dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée. Les soumissions devront étre accompagnées dune feuille de papier timbré de trente millié- mes, ainsi que du regu du versement du cautionnement provisoire susdit. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé 4:— Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de fer de 1'Etat, au Caire. et sous double enveloppe, |'intérienre portant la suscription suivante :. Soumission pour la fourniture de "Cartes non imprimées pour billets de Chemins de fer." Toute sonmission faite ou déposée ultérieu- rement au jocr et 4 l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération. L' Administration ne s'engage pas aa ccepter loffre la plus basse ni 4 donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve en | méme temps le droit de diviser la commande.

div.head: Sudan Government
div.p: NOTICE

Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in the presence of an official or other reliable witness

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
